abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transmission Development
            Project (TDP) for Nigeria were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the focus of the project should not be limited to
            the efficiency of the investments and completion of the
            physical components and the associated outcomes. It is
            important to maintain a vigorous dialogue with the
            Government on broader policy issues and long-term strategy
            for the growth of the sector. In a complex sector, such as
            the power sector in Nigeria with many serious problems and
            huge investment requirements, it is important to identify
            the most critical constraints to efficient delivery of
            services and address those first in order to get the maximum
            impact from limited resources as well as limited
            implementation capacity. TDP was designed to address the
            most critical transmission and dispatch system problems, and
            the later projects are focusing more on system efficiencies
            and increasing gas to power supply in order to maximize
            utilization of the existing operable generating capacity.
            The indicators of project outcomes should be few but fully
            reflective of the project development objectives (PDOs).
            These indicators should be backed by an appropriate model or
            a set of equations for computing the indicators with clear
            identification of controlling and exogenous variables and
            their impact. This should facilitate improved monitoring by
            the implementing authorities, unambiguous evaluation of
            performance at every stage, and identification of corrective action.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transmission Development Project,
            will support the country's Government program of power
            sector reform, and privatization, by addressing the
            requirements of the transmission, and dispatch sub-sectors.
            Project components include: 1) investments, consisting of
            augmentations at five main grid substations, and grid system
            reactive compensation; supply and installation of grid
            system metering to enable the measurement of power supplied
            to unbundled distribution companies; and, the establishment
            of a new National Control Center with Supervisory Control
            and Data Acquisition (SCADA), and Energy Management System
            (EMS) facilities, including associated communications
            requirements. Grid distance protection relays will be
            replaced, to be specifically determined following the power
            system planning study, and, a management information system
            for the Transmission and System Operation Company
            (TransysCo), will be supplied and installed; 2) technical
            assistance, designed to establish, and operate the new
            TransysCo, will develop transmission, and system operations
            related to secondary regulations. Additionally, the
            operation of a wholesale power market will be established.
            Training programs will enhance managerial, legal, technical,
            and financial capabilities, covering the areas of sector
            regulation, financial management, social, and environmental
            issues, and technical aspects on transmission maintenance,
            and system operation; and, 3) the establishment of an
            environment, resettlement, and social unit, funded to
            support monitoring, and evaluation of project related
            environmental, and social issues, including the program for
            HIV/AIDS prevention.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Transmission Development Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transmission Development Project
            will add new transformers and associated facilities at five
            existing substations located at Oshogbo, Kano, Onitsha,
            Benin, and Alaoji. This Environmental Policy Framework
            Evaluation (EPFE) examines the potential issues arising from
            construction of new facilities: a) impact to biological
            resources; b) impacts to human resources arising from
            construction of new facilities; c) noise related to
            construction and operation of large transformers; d) public
            and workplace health and safety associated with past
            management practices at existing substations, including the
            use and disposal of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB)
            containing transformer oils; and e) contamination issues
            associated with ongoing management of facilities. The five
            existing locations all have sufficient land within existing
            perimeters to accommodate the proposed facilities, and no
            biological or social land use impacts are therefore
            anticipated. No residence or sensitive receptors were noted
            in close proximity to the substation sites, and so noise is
            not considered an issue. Leakage and uncontrolled disposal
            of PCB-containing oils has occurred at two existing
            facilities, which may present a risk to workers at the
            sites. To mitigate this, PCB tests will be conducted in all
            facilities initially. If the presence of PCB is confirmed, a
            Phase II audit will be conducted to develop new construction
            plans for minimizing contamination and human exposure.
